Key Arguments: The legislation represents an overreach of government control over online communication, potentially leading to censorship and suppression of public debate.
The bill is based on a report by ACMA, which may have a conflict of interest in recommending increased powers for itself.
The exemption of government publications from regulation suggests a totalitarian approach.
Misinformation and disinformation are difficult to define and apply, leading to potential misuse of the legislation.
The solution to misinformation should be more information and education, not censorship.
Notable Quotes: It leaves the door wide open to government censorship of the sharing of ideas and shutting down of public debate.
Government control over what can be shared via online media is what happens in China; it does not belong in Australia.
The answer to misinformation is more information, not removal of the misinformation, lest it be found to be true after all.
